section.p: The installation of comprises several steps. They are partially executed by the operator, and partially by the OpenStack operator.
The installation of comprises the following steps:

ol.li: Preparing the installation environment - done by the OpenStack operator and the operator.
Configuring the Control Machine - done by the OpenStack operator and the operator.
Installing the offline resources - done by the operator only.
Installing the OpenStack extensions required for the Service - done by the OpenStack operator only.
Installing the Service - done by the operator only.

section.p: As an OpenStack operator, you also install and configure the agents you use for monitoring your OpenStack services. Your tenant users who have booked a virtual machine in OpenStack monitor their machine with libvirt. As an OpenStack operator, you have to make the required libvirt preparations for your tenant users. For details, refer to .
ships with an installer that is based on Ansible. You use it for installing the OpenStack extensions and the required agents.

section.title: Recommended Installation Environment
section.p: The following installation environment is recommended:

li.p: By default, the operator installs the offline resources, the components, and the required agents on one host ( host). To ensure high availability and improve scalability, can also be clustered and installed on multiple hosts. This does not affect your tasks as an OpenStack operator.

As an OpenStack operator, you install the OpenStack extensions and the required agents for the OpenStack Keystone service and the OpenStack Horizon service. Depending on your OpenStack environment, Keystone and Horizon can either be installed on the same or on two separate hosts.
You can install additional agents for monitoring additional OpenStack services as required.

section.p: The installation of the components is managed from a so-called Control Machine.
